cards.back: Application Programming Interface - a way for two programs to talk to each other. Like a waiter in a restaurant: you give your order to the waiter (API), who brings it to the kitchen (server) and returns with your food (data). When talking to LLMs: "I need an API to get weather data" or "The API returns user information"

HyperText Transfer Protocol - the language browsers use to talk to websites. Like sending postcards with specific formats: GET (send me this page), POST (here's data to save), PUT (update this), DELETE (remove this). When talking to LLMs: "Make a GET request to fetch users"

A computer that waits for requests and sends back responses. It 'serves' information. Like a librarian who waits for you to ask for a book, finds it, and gives it to you. When talking to LLMs: "The server stores user data"

Any program that makes requests to a server. Your web browser is a client. You're the customer (client) asking the librarian (server) for books. When talking to LLMs: "The client sends the username to the server"

A common style for building APIs using HTTP. Resources have URLs and you use GET/POST/PUT/DELETE. Example: GET /users (list all), GET /users/123 (get one), POST /users (create), DELETE /users/123 (delete). When talking to LLMs: "Create a REST API for managing products"

A persistent two-way connection between client and server. Unlike HTTP (ask then answer), WebSockets stay open for continuous communication. HTTP is like texting, WebSocket is like a phone call. Use for: chat apps, live updates, games. When talking to LLMs: "Use WebSockets for real-time chat"

A specific address where an API accepts requests. Example: https://api.weather.com/forecast - Base URL: api.weather.com, Endpoint: /forecast. When talking to LLMs: "Create an endpoint for user registration at /api/register"

cards.front: What is a request and response?
cards.back: Request: what the client asks for (URL, method, headers, body). Response: what the server sends back (status code, headers, body with data). When talking to LLMs: "The request sends user data, the response returns the created user"

Numbers indicating what happened: 200s = success (200 OK, 201 Created), 400s = client error (400 Bad Request, 401 Not logged in, 403 Forbidden, 404 Not Found), 500s = server error. When talking to LLMs: "Return a 404 if the user doesn't exist"

Authentication: proving WHO you are (login with password). Authorization: proving WHAT you can do (permissions). Authentication is showing ID at the door, authorization is whether your ticket gets you into VIP. When talking to LLMs: "Add authentication so users must log in"

A string proving you're logged in so you don't send your password every time. Flow: login → get token → include token in requests → server trusts it. Like a wristband at a festival. When talking to LLMs: "Store the auth token and send it with each API request"

HTTPS = HTTP + encryption. SSL/TLS encrypts data so hackers can't read it in transit. HTTP is a postcard anyone can read, HTTPS is a sealed envelope. When talking to LLMs: "Make sure the API uses HTTPS"

A number identifying a specific service on a computer. Common ports: 80 (HTTP), 443 (HTTPS), 3000 (dev servers), 5432 (PostgreSQL). Your computer is an apartment building, ports are apartment numbers. When talking to LLMs: "Run the server on port 3000"

A special address meaning "this computer" - used for development. localhost = 127.0.0.1. Example: http://localhost:3000 means connect to port 3000 on my own computer. When talking to LLMs: "Test the API on localhost before deploying"

Cross-Origin Resource Sharing - security rule controlling which websites can access your API. By default, siteA.com can't fetch from siteB.com unless siteB explicitly allows it. When talking to LLMs: "I'm getting a CORS error" or "Enable CORS so the frontend can call the API"

A way for one service to notify another when something happens. Instead of constantly asking "any updates?", the service calls you. Like the pizza place calling you when your order is ready. When talking to LLMs: "Set up a webhook to receive payment notifications"

Polling: client repeatedly asks "any updates?" (wasteful but simple). Push: server sends updates when they happen (efficient, uses WebSockets or webhooks). When talking to LLMs: "Use WebSockets to push updates instead of polling every 5 seconds"
Small data stored in browser, sent with every request to that website. Used for: staying logged in, remembering preferences, tracking. When talking to LLMs: "Store the session ID in a cookie"

A way to remember a user across requests. HTTP is stateless, so sessions track that it's the same user. User logs in → server creates session → user sends session ID with requests. When talking to LLMs: "Store the shopping cart in the user's session"

Restricting how many requests someone can make in a time period. Prevents abuse. Example: 100 requests per minute. If exceeded, returns 429 Too Many Requests. When talking to LLMs: "Add rate limiting so users can only make 10 API calls per minute"
